===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|つるぎ|yomi=k}}
{{unk.|ja}}. Also read as ''tsuruki'' in {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=つるぎ}} contexts.<ref name="KDJ"/><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref>

A surface analysis suggests that this might be a compound of ''tsuru'' (variously {{ja-l|釣る}} or {{ja-l|吊る}}, meaning “to hang, as at one's side”) + ''ki'', but there is no clear [[etymon]] for the ''ki'' portion. One possibility would be {{m|ja|牙||fang}}, read as ''kiba'' in modern {{etyl|ja|-}} but also appearing as ''ki'' in {{etyl|ojp|-}} contexts. Such usage might parallel the combined {{m|en|tooth}} and {{m|en|blade}} meanings of the term ''ha'', spelled more specifically as {{m|ja|歯||tooth}} and {{m|ja|刃||blade}}, with these two senses listed as [[cognate]]s in Japanese dictionaries.<ref name="KDJ"/><ref name="DJR"/>

More tentative suggestions have been connections to Austronesian, such as {{cog|tl|suligi||dart; short spear}}, but such possibilities seem only [[speculative]] at present.
